title: 112_hr603
content: The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011, also known as the TEAM-Empowerment Act of 2011, includes provisions for individualized transition plans and transition planning services administrative units. The Act also outlines findings and purposes. Congress finds that evidence-based research has shown that youth with significant disabilities benefit from inclusive education, work experience, and paid work while in school, leading to better postsecondary outcomes and sustainable employment. Higher rates of self-determination for individuals with disabilities and their families also result in improved outcomes. Flexible regulations and processes for blending government funds are essential for seamless and collaborative transition strategies. The Act aims to create a holistic system for successful transition of youth with significant disabilities into adulthood, focusing on high expectations and flexibility in blending government funds for better outcomes. Agency officials providing supports during the transition process need additional training to address individual needs effectively. Create a holistic system for successful transition of youth with significant disabilities into adulthood, focusing on high expectations, equality of opportunity, self-determination, and post-secondary options leading to competitive integrated employment. Promote innovative strategies for academic, professional, and social inclusion, and coordinate specific services for effective transition. To ensure successful transition of youth with significant disabilities, better define and coordinate specific services, eliminate barriers, and promote collaboration among stakeholders. SEC. 3. INDIVIDUALIZED TRANSITION PLANS; TRANSITION PLANNING AND SERVICES ADMINISTRATIVE UNITS. Title I of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 is amended by adding a new section on Adult Transition System with defined terms. The term 'asset development' refers to a strategy to help low-income workers and job seekers, including individuals with disabilities, achieve economic security through various means such as effective money management, education, home ownership, and retirement planning. The term 'individualized education program' is defined in the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, and 'integrated employment' refers to work at minimum or competitive wages with benefits in a typical work setting for employees with disabilities. The term 'integrated employment' in the Disabilities Education Act refers to work compensated at minimum or competitive wages with benefits in a typical work setting where employees with disabilities interact with nondisabled co-workers, have opportunities for advancement, and are preferably engaged in full-time employment. The term 'ITP' refers to an individual transition plan, and 'local educational agency' and 'secondary school' have specific meanings as defined in other education acts. The curr_chunk provides definitions for key terms related to the Disabilities Education Act, including 'local educational agency,' 'secondary school,' 'State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency,' and 'TPS administrative unit.' These definitions clarify the roles and responsibilities within the educational system. The curr_chunk defines 'transition services' as activities for students with disabilities to transition from school to post-school activities, such as education, training, employment, and independent living. Transition services for students with disabilities include a coordinated set of activities based on individual needs and preferences. This includes instruction, community experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, youth development, self-advocacy training, family involvement, and other supports. Transition services for students with disabilities involve a coordinated set of activities focused on individual needs and preferences. This includes self-advocacy training, family involvement, and acquisition of daily living skills. The activities should lead to outcomes like post-secondary education, integrated employment, independent living, and community participation, excluding facility-based employment settings. State assistance under SEC. 172 involves the Secretary making competitive grants to States for carrying out required activities. Payments are allocated based on a formula considering the number of individuals to be served. SEC. 173 focuses on individualized transition plans. Each State receiving assistance must develop an individual transition plan for individuals with developmental disabilities transitioning into adulthood. The plan aims to coordinate services for integrated employment, postsecondary education, independent living, and community engagement. The plan should be coordinated with existing transition services and developed within 30 days after exiting secondary school. An individualized education program must be developed for individuals with disabilities before exiting secondary school, applicable until age 26, reviewed annually, and developed in in-person meetings led by the State's intellectual and developmental disabilities agency. An Individualized Transition Plan (ITP) must be established for individuals with disabilities, involving key stakeholders such as the individual, family, transition broker, vocational rehabilitation agency, service providers, transition coordinator, assistive technology experts, and workforce development representatives. The ITP should include strategies for the transition process. An Individualized Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with disabilities involves key stakeholders like the individual, family, transition broker, vocational rehabilitation agency, service providers, transition coordinator, assistive technology experts, and workforce development representatives. The ITP includes strategies for implementing service models and practices that address postsecondary educational experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, development and leadership, connecting activities, family involvement, and economic self-sufficiency goals. The Individualized Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with disabilities involves key stakeholders and includes strategies for implementing service models that address postsecondary education, career preparation, work-based learning, development, leadership, family involvement, and economic self-sufficiency goals such as tax benefits, work incentives, savings plans, education financing, and budget management. "SEC. 174. TRANSITION PLANNING AND SERVICES ADMINISTRATIVE UNIT." Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must establish a transition planning and services (TPS) administrative unit within the State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency. The primary focus of the TPS unit is to help individuals with developmental disabilities transition from the secondary school system to adulthood. Responsibilities include developing and implementing individual transition plans (ITPs) and employing transition brokers. The TPS administrative unit must employ transition brokers to facilitate coordination among State agencies in developing ITPs and provide assistance to individuals with developmental disabilities in navigating support services. Transition brokers must meet specific qualifications to serve in this role. Transition brokers of the TPS administrative unit must have qualifications related to developmental disabilities, benefits planning, transition services, employment, job development, and negotiation with State stakeholders. They should also have experience in workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, and job development. Transition brokers of the TPS administrative unit should have experience in workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, job development, asset development, economic self-sufficiency tools, self-direction, and person-centered planning processes. The TPS administrative unit assigns a transition broker to individuals with developmental disabilities upon selection by the individual, family, or guardian, and approval by the State agency. They also provide training on self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring to improve abilities. The TPS administrative unit offers strategies and training on self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring for individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. They also provide information on Federal and State services, supports, and regulations, including asset development and eligibility criteria for means-tested services. The State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency facilitates collaboration among key State agencies to improve services for individuals with developmental disabilities during the transition into adulthood. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress evaluating the implementation and effectiveness of the subtitle, including the number of individuals with Individual Transition Plans (ITPs) developed, progress in ITP objectives, and demographic information of individuals with ITPs. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 to carry out this subtitle.
